docs.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers passed an amnesty for ethnic Albanian guerrillas, a move both sides hailed as a vital step to solidify a peace that has held tenuously since last summer. The amnesty was long considered one of the most sensitive parts of a broad peace plan that ended six months of fighting but has yet to move completely through Parliament. The law does not cover possible crimes investigated by the international tribunal in The Hague, which has said it is looking into several incidents involving both Macedonians and Albanians. Ian Fisher (NYT)

docs.snippet: The former first family of the Balkans has had a very bad year. The father, Slobodan, was packed off to The Hague and charged with genocide. His trial, the most important war crimes prosecution since Nuremberg, begins next month. The son, Marko, w...
docs.lead_paragraph: The former first family of the Balkans has had a very bad year. The father, Slobodan, was packed off to The Hague and charged with genocide. His trial, the most important war crimes prosecution since Nuremberg, begins next month. The son, Marko, was indicted for threatening to chop up an opposition activist with a rotary saw and throw his body parts in a river. The daughter, Marija, went on trial for a father's pistol during a drug-and-alcohol-induced frenzy 10 months ago, on the night her father was arrested in the presidential mansion. And the mother, Mirjana, in the first of what Serbian police promise will be many criminal charges, was indicted for improperly using her influence to secure an apartment for her grandson's baby sitter. One afternoon earlier this winter in Belgrade, I met with Slobodan Milosevic's wife. She received me in the cavernous and nearly empty villa that is the headquarters of her increasingly marginal political party, the Yugoslav Left. She was not in a good mood. She had just come home from her fifth visit with her husband at a detention center in The Hague. Upon her return, she learned of her son's rotary-saw indictment. Her daughter was preparing for trial on weapons charges. And she was due in court in three days to answer charges about the baby sitter's apartment. As she sat down with a translator to talk in a small, ground-floor office, I asked Mirjana Markovic (she has always used her maiden name) why she thought international and Serbian courts were now trying to put her entire family in prison.
docs.abstract: Blaine Harden article on Slobodan Milosevic and pathology of his delusional family; photos; strong-willed wife Mirjana Markovic faces first of what Serbian police promise will be many criminal charges, indictment for using influence improperly; notoriously violent son Marko is charged with threatening to chop up opposition activist, and daughter, Marija, has gone on trial for brandishing pistol during drug-and-alcohol frenzy ten months ago; shared delusions of Milosevics were for 13 years governing principles of Serbia, as four lost wars taught Serbs to see themselves as victims of ever-expanding cospiracy; myths that secured hold on power also played key role in downfall, but Milosevic's family, moneyed friends and former police protectors continue to linger on in democratic Serbia, allowing Markovic to live in official presidential residence (L)

But Colombian guerrillas are increasingly crossing into this region in a search for affluent Venezuelans to kidnap and extort, so Mr. Ayala's visits are not the same. His family does not accompany him, and when Mr. Ayala makes the trip, he varies his routine and leaves before dark.

docs.lead_paragraph: The police in Northern Ireland arrested two men today in the slaying of Daniel McColgan, a Catholic mailman who was shot dead by Protestant gunmen on Saturday morning as he reported for work in the northern outskirts of Belfast. The Ulster Defense Association, the province's largest Protestant paramilitary organization, claimed responsibility for the killing, which it said was in retaliation for attacks on Protestant communities. A group calling itself the Red Hand Defenders, a cover name used by the U.D.A. and other Protestant paramilitary groups, had previously taken responsibility and had issued public death threats to Catholic postal workers and schoolteachers in Northern Ireland.

Vorontsov, the United Nations official responsible for tracking Kuwaitis who disappeared in the months after Iraq's 1990 invasion, said Iraq would sooner or later have to reveal the fate of more than 600 missing Kuwaitis and others who disappeared. Mr. Voronstsov, who spoke in Cairo, is touring the region for talks on how to increase Iraqi cooperation on the issue. docs.lead_paragraph: India's defense minister, George Fernandes, said today that the steps Pakistan had taken so far to crack down on Islamic militant groups fighting India in Kashmir were illusory and had done nothing to reduce the level of terrorist violence. Mr. Fernandes, who is overseeing a vast military mobilization along India's border with Pakistan, said flatly that he did not believe that Pakistan's military intelligence agency had been ordered to end its support of groups fighting what they call a holy war against India, as senior Pakistani officials said on Tuesday.
docs.abstract: Indian Min George Fernandes holds Pakistan's crackdown on Islamic militant groups fighting India in Kashmir is illusory and has not reduced level of terrorist violence, interview; holds Pakistan seeks to mislead United States, not disable militants; says India will exercise military option if diplomatic moves fail to get Pakistan to take effective action against groups; Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee scores what he calls Pakistan's sponsorship of terrorism in Kashmir; map; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the circumspect world of the judges at the United Nations war crimes tribunal, Patricia M. Wald has stood out and knocked down quite a few taboos. To begin with, there was her American-style informality in a place of stiff etiquette. Judge Wald, who had twice refused the post of attorney general in the United States, first turned heads here by eating in the canteen, where tribunal judges rarely tread. She raised some very august eyebrows as she kept wandering into the clerks' section to chat or fetch documents to help judge the atrocities committed in the 1990's wars of the former Yugoslavia.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Korean War veteran who apparently lied about his role in a massacre of civilians that came to light 50 years after it occurred was charged today with filing false claims at the Veterans Affairs Department. Prosecutors said the veteran, Edward Lee Daily of Clarksville, Tenn., had bilked the government of hundreds of thousands of dollars in compensation and medical claims by falsely asserting that he had been wounded in North Korea and had been a prisoner of war.
docs.abstract: Edward Lee Daily, whose account of incident in which he and other American soldiers allegedly killed hundreds of unarmed civilians in July 1950 at No Gun Ri during Korean War led to 2000 probe and statement of regret by Pres Clinton, apparently invented his involvement; Army records show he was not with unit at site and that documents showing he was prisoner of war and won battlefield awards were fabricated; he is charged with filing false claims at Veterans Affairs Department and bilking government of hundreds of thousands of dollars in compensation and medical expenses (M)
